conclusion: The problem involves determining the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface of a hemispherical shell where light rays are transmitted, using Snell's law and geometric properties.

The hemispherical shell has an inner radius \( R \) and an outer radius \( \sqrt{2}R \). A parallel beam of light with a cross-sectional radius of \( R \) is incident on the inner surface, parallel to the axis of symmetry.
The refractive index of the transparent medium is given, and multiple reflections are not considered.
The angle of incidence \( i \) and the angle of refraction \( \theta \) are related by Snell's law: \( n \sin i = \sin \theta \).
The distance from the center \( O \) to the point of incidence on the inner surface is \( R \), and the distance to the point of incidence on the outer surface is \( \sqrt{2}R \).
The angle \( \theta \) can be related to the geometry of the triangle formed by the radius and the incident and refracted rays.
The angle \( \theta \) is such that the light ray just grazes the outer surface of the hemispherical shell, meaning the angle of incidence at the outer surface is \( 90^\circ \).
Using the relationship \( n \sin i = \sin \theta \) and the geometry of the triangle, the radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface is calculated to be \( 2R \).
The radius of the circular boundary on the outer surface of the hemispherical shell where light rays are transmitted is \( 2R \).
